description: Fundamentals of Statistics. Descriptive statistics and simple linear regression. Emphasis is on the development of statistical thinking and applications are directed towards the behavioral sciences, especially psychology, and medicine. Topics include probability, statistical inference, hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.
name: INTRODUCTORY STATISTICS

values.comments: Fundamentals of Statistics. Descriptive statistics and simple linear regression. Emphasis is on the development of statistical thinking and applications are directed towards the behavioral sciences, especially psychology, and medicine. Topics include probability, statistical inference, hypothesis testing and confidence intervals. The goal of this course is to develop basic tools for data analysis, probability and statistical methods. Key topics covered in the course include exploratory data analysis, regression, probability, estimation, and hypothesis testing. Knowledge of high school algebra is required.   Students overall enjoyed the material presented in this course. Students commented that they thought this was “a good introductory statistics course for people in the College,” and felt that they truly learned a lot in terms of skills and knowledge. Those with more of a mathematical background found the course to be somewhat easier, while those with less of a mathematical-mind found the course to be difficult. However, students from both sides agreed that “this was a surprisingly interesting course” that taught valuable and applicable lessons in statistics.   Students agreed that Professor Wyner is “an entertaining lecturer” who “makes statistics fun.” Several students commented that his “enthusiasm and passion for teaching” and statistics is “contagious.” Students further appreciated Professor Wyner’s availability to students and helpful office hours, as well as praised his organization of class notes and lecture slides. However, while students felt that Professor Wyner “made the topic engaging and relatable,” some found it difficult to “focus during lectures” due to the lecture slides.   Most students agreed that the midterm and final exams for this course were quite difficult, especially compared to the material presented in lecture and on homework. Students felt that the weekly homework assignments were educational but also required a strict work ethic. Since the homework counts for 20% of the grade, students “have to consistently put in effort.” Some felt that the grading on the exams was harsh and that “more weight should be placed on homework.”
